conflictDescription: User Story A wants to access patient data quickly without permission, but User Story B wants to control sharing to respect privacy. These are opposite requirements about data access and sharing, which cannot both be fully satisfied at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see health data of all my clients in one place and control what information is shared to respect their privacy.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to balance quick access with privacy control by adding conditions and roles to respect privacy and care efficiency.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with necessary permissions, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see health data of my clients in one place and control sharing to respect their privacy.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data quickly without permission, while User Story B forbids logging certain vital signs to protect privacy, creating a conflict between unrestricted access and strict privacy control.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control what vital signs are logged for each client to protect their privacy and only record needed data.
resolutionDescription: Both stories are updated to balance quick access and privacy control by allowing fast data access with permission policies and controlled logging of vital signs.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with proper permissions, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control which vital signs are logged for each client to protect privacy while allowing needed data collection.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to access patient data quickly without permission, while User Story B wants to see only data allowed by the client. These are opposite instructions for data access under the same event of needing patient data.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see only the health data clients allow me to see, so I respect their privacy and keep their trust.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to define access rules based on user roles and permissions, ensuring quick access for nurses but respecting client consent for informal caregivers.
newUserStoryASummary: As a nurse, I want quick access to patient health data with proper permissions, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see only health data allowed by clients, so I respect their privacy and keep their trust.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants automatic quick access to patient data without permission, while User Story B wants to stop automatic sharing of private data for clinical reasons. These are opposite instructions for the same event of sharing patient data.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to stop automatic sharing of my clients' private data for clinical reasons, so I can keep their trust and privacy safe.
resolutionDescription: We clarify context by adding conditions under which data sharing is allowed or stopped, making the system adapt based on user consent and privacy needs.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want quick access to patient health data with proper permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to stop automatic sharing of private data without consent, so I can keep trust and privacy safe.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects the system to provide quick access to patient data without permission, while User Story B expects the system to respect clients' wishes for less guidance, which may include limiting access or explanations. These opposite expectations conflict on how the system should behave regarding patient data access and guidance.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to follow each client’s wish for less guidance, so I can support their independence and avoid causing frustration.
resolutionDescription: We adjust both stories to balance quick access with respecting client preferences, applying context-aware permission checks.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with proper permission, so I can support care efficiently.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to respect clients' wishes for less guidance and control access, so I support their independence.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to access patient data quickly without needing permission, while User Story B wants to explain data sharing clearly and respect client choices, implying permission is needed. These are opposite expectations about data access under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to explain data sharing to clients clearly and respect their choices, so they feel safe and in control.
resolutionDescription: Adjust both stories to balance quick access and respecting user consent by adding context-aware permissions and clear explanations.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient data quickly with proper consent, so I can support care efficiently.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to explain data sharing clearly and respect client choices, so they feel safe and in control.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires quick access to patient data without permission, while User Story B allows choosing what data to share to protect privacy, which forbids unrestricted access. These are opposite expectations about data access.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose what sensor data and notifications to share for each client, so I respect their privacy and keep care personal.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to balance quick data access and user privacy by introducing role-based access controls and user consent options.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want quick access to patient health data with necessary permissions, so I can support care efficiently.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control which sensor data to share, so I respect privacy and keep care personal.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to access patient data quickly without needing permission, but User Story B wants to prepare visit plans that respect privacy, implying data access should be limited or controlled. These two impose opposite expectations about permission and privacy when accessing patient data.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to prepare visit plans that respect each older adult’s privacy and match their personal needs.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: User Story A is updated to include controlled and authorized access to patient data only during urgent care, while User Story B remains unchanged to ensure privacy in visit plans.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with proper authorization in urgent cases, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to prepare visit plans that respect each older adult’s privacy and match their personal needs.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data quickly without needing permission, while User Story B requires checking privacy settings to avoid sharing data without clear permission. These impose opposite expectations on data access at the same event.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly without needing their permission, so I can support care efficiently during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to check clients' privacy settings myself, so I respect their choices and never share data without their clear permission.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to balance quick access for nurses with respecting privacy through permission checks, using a context-aware policy to allow access only under emergency or authorized conditions.
newUserStoryASummary: As a nurse, I want to access patient data quickly in emergencies, so I can support care efficiently while respecting privacy.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a caregiver, I want to check privacy settings before accessing data, so I respect clients' choices and protect their information.

conflictDescription: User Story A asks for quick access to patient data without permission, while User Story B requires control over what information is shared to respect privacy. These are opposite expectations about data access under the same condition.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see health data of all my clients in one place and control what information is shared to respect their privacy.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to include permission controls and privacy respect, ensuring quick access is allowed only with consent, resolving the opposite expectation on data access.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want quick access to my patient's activity and nutrition data with their permission, so that I can monitor health efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see health data of my clients in one place and control what information is shared to protect their privacy.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data quickly without permission, while User Story B forbids recording vital signs beyond what is needed to protect privacy, including controlling data logging. These two stories conflict because one demands unrestricted data access and the other strictly limits data collection and access.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control what vital signs are logged for each client to protect their privacy and only record needed data.
resolutionDescription: User Story A is updated to require quick access to patient data with necessary permissions, while User Story B is updated to allow logging only essential vital signs with user consent. This balances quick access and privacy control.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly with permission, so that I can monitor health during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control logging of essential vital signs with consent, so that patient privacy is protected.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data without permission, but User Story B forbids accessing data beyond what clients allow. These opposite instructions for data access create a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see only the health data clients allow me to see, so I respect their privacy and keep their trust.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to respect data access permissions while allowing timely health monitoring, balancing privacy and care needs.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want quick access to patients' activity and nutrition data with proper permission, so I can monitor health efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see only the health data clients allow me to see, so I respect their privacy and keep their trust.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires automatic access to patient data without permission, while User Story B forbids automatic sharing of private data for clinical reasons. These are opposite expectations on the same event of data sharing.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to stop automatic sharing of my clients' private data for clinical reasons, so I can keep their trust and privacy safe.
resolutionDescription: Applied a contextual policy layer where nurse access requires patient consent or emergency override, and caregivers can stop sharing under normal conditions to protect privacy.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly with permission or in emergencies, so I can monitor health during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to stop automatic sharing of my clients' private data except in emergencies, to keep their trust and privacy safe.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data quickly without permission, while User Story B requires respecting the client's wish for less guidance, which may include limiting access. These are opposite expectations about accessing and using patient data without consent.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to follow each client’s wish for less guidance, so I can support their independence and avoid causing frustration.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by limiting quick access to patient data to cases where consent is given or in urgent situations, balancing nurse monitoring needs and respecting client wishes.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly with proper consent or in urgent cases, so I can monitor health efficiently.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to respect each client’s wish for less guidance to support their independence and avoid frustration.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data without permission to monitor health, while User Story B insists on respecting patient choices and explaining data sharing clearly, forbidding access without consent. These two impose opposite constraints on data access.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to explain data sharing to clients clearly and respect their choices, so they feel safe and in control.
generalResolutionType: Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: User Story A is updated to require accessing patient data only with consent during busy shifts, respecting User Story B's insistence on patient control and clear explanation.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly with their permission, so I can monitor health during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to explain data sharing to clients clearly and respect their choices, so they feel safe and in control.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data quickly without permission, while User Story B requires choosing what data to share to respect privacy. These impose opposite expectations on data access under the same condition.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose what sensor data and notifications to share for each client, so I respect their privacy and keep care personal.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: We update User Story A to require permission before accessing patient data, respecting privacy, while User Story B remains unchanged to choose what data to share.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly with their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose what sensor data and notifications to share for each client, so I respect their privacy and keep care personal.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient data quickly without permission, while User Story B requires respecting the older adult's privacy in visit plans, forbidding access without consent. These are opposite expectations about data access.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to prepare visit plans that respect each older adult’s privacy and match their personal needs.
resolutionDescription: Both stories are updated to respect privacy while allowing timely access under consent or emergency, balancing quick data access with privacy needs.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient activity and nutrition data quickly with proper consent, so that I can monitor health efficiently during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to prepare visit plans that respect each older adult’s privacy and personal needs, ensuring data is accessed only with consent.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires the system to allow access to patient data without permission, while User Story B requires respecting privacy settings and not sharing data without clear permission. These are opposite expectations about data access under the same condition.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly without their permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to check clients' privacy settings myself, so I respect their choices and never share data without their clear permission.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to respect privacy while allowing efficient access under clear permission, balancing quick monitoring with consent.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access my patient's activity and nutrition data quickly with proper permission to monitor health during busy shifts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to check clients' privacy settings to respect their choices and share data only with clear permission.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to force hard exercises without easy options, while User Story B wants ALFRED to follow the client's wish for less guidance and minimal instructions, which may include allowing easier exercise options. These are opposite instructions on how ALFRED should handle exercise difficulty and guidance.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want ALFRED to force patients to do hard exercises without allowing easy options so I can keep control and push their limits.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to follow each client’s wish for less guidance, so I can support their independence and avoid causing frustration.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to include context-aware exercise guidance that adapts to user preferences while maintaining safety and encouragement.
newUserStoryASummary: As a nurse, I want ALFRED to encourage challenging exercises while adapting to users' abilities, so patients are safely pushed to improve.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a caregiver, I want ALFRED to respect users' wishes for less guidance and easier options, so they feel independent and not frustrated.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to force patients to do hard exercises only, forbidding easy options, while User Story B wants ALFRED to support clients' interest in activities to keep them happy and involved, which implies allowing easier or enjoyable options. These are opposite instructions for the exercise operation.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want ALFRED to force patients to do hard exercises without allowing easy options so I can keep control and push their limits.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to help me support my clients' interest in physical and mental activities so they feel happy and involved in their care.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow ALFRED to recommend exercise difficulty based on patient condition and preferences, balancing control and enjoyment.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want ALFRED to encourage patients to do appropriate exercises that challenge them safely, so I can help improve their health.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to support clients with activities they enjoy, including easy options, so they stay happy and involved.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to force hard exercises only, not allowing easy options. User Story B wants plans that respect personal needs, which may include easy or adapted exercises. These two impose opposite instructions on exercise difficulty.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want ALFRED to force patients to do hard exercises without allowing easy options so I can keep control and push their limits.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to prepare visit plans that respect each older adult’s privacy and match their personal needs.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow exercise plans to balance challenge and personal needs, enabling flexible exercise difficulty based on user condition and caregiver input.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want ALFRED to encourage challenging exercises while adapting difficulty to users' abilities, so I can support progress safely.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to prepare exercise plans that respect personal needs and privacy, so users feel comfortable and motivated.
